title: Introduction to data manipulation in R with the tidyverse packages
text: document contains quick introduction data manipulation R using packages tidyverse: maggrittr, dplyr, tidyr.

title: Introduction to data manipulation in R with the tidyverse packages
code: library(ciatej2024) library(palmerpenguins) library(dplyr) library(tidyr) library(magrittr)

title: Introduction to data manipulation in R with the tidyverse packages
text: Use magrittr package load pipe (%>%) operator. pipe operator helps : Chain together output input several function calls. Improve code readability. example: R provides ’s native pipe:
code: letters %>%     head %>%     length #> [1] 6 letters |>      head() |>      length() #> [1] 6

title: Introduction to data manipulation in R with the tidyverse packages
text: Tidy data means: Observations rows table (1 observation per row). Variables columns table (1 variable per column). “palmer penguins” dataset example tidy data: matrix gene expression example data “tidy” format.
code: penguins |>     head() #> # A tibble: 6 × 8 #>   species island    bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g #>   <fct>   <fct>              <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>       <int> #> 1 Adelie  Torgersen           39.1          18.7               181        3750 #> 2 Adelie  Torgersen           39.5          17.4               186        3800 #> 3 Adelie  Torgersen           40.3          18                 195        3250 #> 4 Adelie  Torgersen           NA            NA                  NA          NA #> 5 Adelie  Torgersen           36.7          19.3               193        3450 #> 6 Adelie  Torgersen           39.3          20.6               190        3650 #> # ℹ 2 more variables: sex <fct>, year <int> zgenes_path <- system.file(     "extdata", "zgenes.tsv", package = "ciatej2024", mustWork = TRUE ) zgenes <- read.table(zgenes_path, sep = "\t", header = TRUE, row.names = 1) head(zgenes) #>                    Ctl1 Ctl3 Ctl5 Trt9 Trt11 Trt13 #> ENSDARG00000000001  304  129  339  102    16   617 #> ENSDARG00000000002  605  637  406   82   230  1245 #> ENSDARG00000000018  391  235  217  554   451   565 #> ENSDARG00000000019 2979 4729 7002 7309  9395  3349 #> ENSDARG00000000068   89  356   41  149    45    44 #> ENSDARG00000000069  312  184  844  269   513   243

title: Introduction to data manipulation in R with the tidyverse packages
text: dplyr package provides verbs (function) manipulate data.frames (tables). Filter observations (rows) selecting variables (columns). Transform (mutate) variables. Summarize data. Join relational tables. Let’s clean palmer penguins dataset: Use View() explore dataset.
code: head(penguins_raw) #> # A tibble: 6 × 17 #>   studyName `Sample Number` Species          Region Island Stage `Individual ID` #>   <chr>               <dbl> <chr>            <chr>  <chr>  <chr> <chr>           #> 1 PAL0708                 1 Adelie Penguin … Anvers Torge… Adul… N1A1            #> 2 PAL0708                 2 Adelie Penguin … Anvers Torge… Adul… N1A2            #> 3 PAL0708                 3 Adelie Penguin … Anvers Torge… Adul… N2A1            #> 4 PAL0708                 4 Adelie Penguin … Anvers Torge… Adul… N2A2            #> 5 PAL0708                 5 Adelie Penguin … Anvers Torge… Adul… N3A1            #> 6 PAL0708                 6 Adelie Penguin … Anvers Torge… Adul… N3A2            #> # ℹ 10 more variables: `Clutch Completion` <chr>, `Date Egg` <date>, #> #   `Culmen Length (mm)` <dbl>, `Culmen Depth (mm)` <dbl>, #> #   `Flipper Length (mm)` <dbl>, `Body Mass (g)` <dbl>, Sex <chr>, #> #   `Delta 15 N (o/oo)` <dbl>, `Delta 13 C (o/oo)` <dbl>, Comments <chr>

title: Introduction to data manipulation in R with the tidyverse packages
text: Use rename rename variables:
code: dat <- penguins_raw dat <- dat |>      rename(         study_name = studyName,         sample_number = `Sample Number`,         species = Species,         region = Region,         island = Island,         stage = Stage,         id = `Individual ID`,         clutch_completion = `Clutch Completion`,         date_egg = `Date Egg`,         culmen_length = `Culmen Length (mm)`,         culmen_depth = `Culmen Depth (mm)`,         flipper_length = `Flipper Length (mm)`,         body_mass = `Body Mass (g)`,         sex = Sex,         delta_n = `Delta 15 N (o/oo)`,         delat_c = `Delta 13 C (o/oo)`,         comments = Comments     ) colnames(dat) #>  [1] "study_name"        "sample_number"     "species"           #>  [4] "region"            "island"            "stage"             #>  [7] "id"                "clutch_completion" "date_egg"          #> [10] "culmen_length"     "culmen_depth"      "flipper_length"    #> [13] "body_mass"         "sex"               "delta_n"           #> [16] "delat_c"           "comments"

title: Introduction to data manipulation in R with the tidyverse packages
text: Use select select variables remove variables
code: dat <- dat |>      select(         species, island, culmen_length, culmen_depth, flipper_length,         body_mass, sex     ) colnames(dat) #> [1] "species"        "island"         "culmen_length"  "culmen_depth"   #> [5] "flipper_length" "body_mass"      "sex"

title: Introduction to data manipulation in R with the tidyverse packages
text: Use filter filter rows:
code: ## There are shorter ways, but it's out of the scope of this material. dat <- dat |>      filter(         !is.na(culmen_length), !is.na(culmen_depth),         !is.na(flipper_length), !is.na(body_mass), !is.na(sex)     ) head(dat) #> # A tibble: 6 × 7 #>   species       island culmen_length culmen_depth flipper_length body_mass sex   #>   <chr>         <chr>          <dbl>        <dbl>          <dbl>     <dbl> <chr> #> 1 Adelie Pengu… Torge…          39.1         18.7            181      3750 MALE  #> 2 Adelie Pengu… Torge…          39.5         17.4            186      3800 FEMA… #> 3 Adelie Pengu… Torge…          40.3         18              195      3250 FEMA… #> 4 Adelie Pengu… Torge…          36.7         19.3            193      3450 FEMA… #> 5 Adelie Pengu… Torge…          39.3         20.6            190      3650 MALE  #> 6 Adelie Pengu… Torge…          38.9         17.8            181      3625 FEMA…

title: Introduction to data manipulation in R with the tidyverse packages
text: Use mutate transform data. works numeric character variables.
code: table(dat$species) #>  #>       Adelie Penguin (Pygoscelis adeliae)  #>                                       146  #> Chinstrap penguin (Pygoscelis antarctica)  #>                                        68  #>         Gentoo penguin (Pygoscelis papua)  #>                                       119 dat <- dat |>      mutate(         species = sub(" .+$", "", species),         sex = case_when(             sex == "MALE" ~ "M",             sex == "FEMALE" ~ "F"         ),         body_mass = round(body_mass / 1000, 1)     ) head(dat) #> # A tibble: 6 × 7 #>   species island    culmen_length culmen_depth flipper_length body_mass sex   #>   <chr>   <chr>             <dbl>        <dbl>          <dbl>     <dbl> <chr> #> 1 Adelie  Torgersen          39.1         18.7            181       3.8 M     #> 2 Adelie  Torgersen          39.5         17.4            186       3.8 F     #> 3 Adelie  Torgersen          40.3         18              195       3.2 F     #> 4 Adelie  Torgersen          36.7         19.3            193       3.5 F     #> 5 Adelie  Torgersen          39.3         20.6            190       3.6 M     #> 6 Adelie  Torgersen          38.9         17.8            181       3.6 F

title: Introduction to data manipulation in R with the tidyverse packages
text: Use group_by group variables summarize create summaries:
code: dat_summary <- dat |>      group_by(species, island, sex) |>      summarize(         mean_culmen_length = mean(culmen_length, na.rm = TRUE),         mean_culmen_depth = mean(culmen_depth, na.rm = TRUE),         mean_flipper_length = flipper_length,         mean_body_mass = body_mass,         n = n()     ) |>      ungroup() summary(dat_summary) #>    species             island              sex            mean_culmen_length #>  Length:333         Length:333         Length:333         Min.   :36.91      #>  Class :character   Class :character   Class :character   1st Qu.:40.07      #>  Mode  :character   Mode  :character   Mode  :character   Median :45.56      #>                                                           Mean   :43.99      #>                                                           3rd Qu.:49.47      #>                                                           Max.   :51.09      #>  mean_culmen_depth mean_flipper_length mean_body_mass        n         #>  Min.   :14.24     Min.   :172         Min.   :2.700   Min.   :22.00   #>  1st Qu.:15.72     1st Qu.:190         1st Qu.:3.500   1st Qu.:24.00   #>  Median :17.59     Median :197         Median :4.000   Median :34.00   #>  Mean   :17.16     Mean   :201         Mean   :4.208   Mean   :38.99   #>  3rd Qu.:18.84     3rd Qu.:213         3rd Qu.:4.800   3rd Qu.:58.00   #>  Max.   :19.39     Max.   :231         Max.   :6.300   Max.   :61.00

title: Introduction to data manipulation in R with the tidyverse packages
text: count shortcut group_by summarize(n = n()). can use arrange order data. Let’s reorder data know island larger number samples:
code: dat |>      count(island) |>      arrange(-n) #> # A tibble: 3 × 2 #>   island        n #>   <chr>     <int> #> 1 Biscoe      163 #> 2 Dream       123 #> 3 Torgersen    47

title: Introduction to data manipulation in R with the tidyverse packages
text: tidyr provides functions change structure data. allows transform non-tidy data tidy data. pivot_longer changes structure data “tidy” format. pivot_wider opposite pivot_longer. Using example (zebrafish data): can revert operation pivot_wider: Using mutate can group treatment create summary:
code: zg <- zgenes |>      tibble::rownames_to_column(var = "gene") |>      pivot_longer(         names_to = "sample", values_to = "expr", cols = 2:last_col()     ) head(zg) #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>   gene               sample  expr #>   <chr>              <chr>  <int> #> 1 ENSDARG00000000001 Ctl1     304 #> 2 ENSDARG00000000001 Ctl3     129 #> 3 ENSDARG00000000001 Ctl5     339 #> 4 ENSDARG00000000001 Trt9     102 #> 5 ENSDARG00000000001 Trt11     16 #> 6 ENSDARG00000000001 Trt13    617 zg |>      pivot_wider(         names_from = "sample", values_from = "expr"     ) |>      tibble::column_to_rownames(var = "gene") |>      head() #>                    Ctl1 Ctl3 Ctl5 Trt9 Trt11 Trt13 #> ENSDARG00000000001  304  129  339  102    16   617 #> ENSDARG00000000002  605  637  406   82   230  1245 #> ENSDARG00000000018  391  235  217  554   451   565 #> ENSDARG00000000019 2979 4729 7002 7309  9395  3349 #> ENSDARG00000000068   89  356   41  149    45    44 #> ENSDARG00000000069  312  184  844  269   513   243 zg |>      mutate(Treatment = sub("\\d+$", "", sample)) |>      group_by(gene, Treatment) |>      summarize(         mean = mean(expr, na.rm = TRUE),         sd = sd(expr, na.rm = TRUE),         n = n()     ) |>      ungroup() |>      head() #> `summarise()` has grouped output by 'gene'. You can override using the #> `.groups` argument. #> # A tibble: 6 × 5 #>   gene               Treatment  mean    sd     n #>   <chr>              <chr>     <dbl> <dbl> <int> #> 1 ENSDARG00000000001 Ctl        257. 113.      3 #> 2 ENSDARG00000000001 Trt        245  325.      3 #> 3 ENSDARG00000000002 Ctl        549. 125.      3 #> 4 ENSDARG00000000002 Trt        519  633.      3 #> 5 ENSDARG00000000018 Ctl        281   95.7     3 #> 6 ENSDARG00000000018 Trt        523.  62.9     3

title: Introduction to data manipulation in R with the tidyverse packages
text: dplyr provide *join functions merge related tables based one variables. example, airway dataset “airway” package Bioconductor. Import data (copy provided package): One dataset needs converted tidy format: Now can use `dplyr::left_join’ merge datasets: Using dplyr verbs:
code: dat_types <- c("sample", "gene", "expr") names(dat_types) <- dat_types airway <- lapply(dat_types, \(x) {     fpath <- system.file(         "extdata", paste0("airway_", x, "_data.tsv"),         package = "ciatej2024", mustWork = TRUE     )     read.table(         file = fpath, header = TRUE, sep = "\t"     ) |>          as_tibble() }) lapply(airway, head) #> $sample #> # A tibble: 6 × 9 #>   Run        SampleName cell   dex   albut avgLength Experiment Sample BioSample #>   <chr>      <chr>      <chr>  <chr> <chr>     <int> <chr>      <chr>  <chr>     #> 1 SRR1039508 GSM1275862 N61311 untrt untrt       126 SRX384345  SRS50… SAMN0242… #> 2 SRR1039509 GSM1275863 N61311 trt   untrt       126 SRX384346  SRS50… SAMN0242… #> 3 SRR1039512 GSM1275866 N0526… untrt untrt       126 SRX384349  SRS50… SAMN0242… #> 4 SRR1039513 GSM1275867 N0526… trt   untrt        87 SRX384350  SRS50… SAMN0242… #> 5 SRR1039516 GSM1275870 N0806… untrt untrt       120 SRX384353  SRS50… SAMN0242… #> 6 SRR1039517 GSM1275871 N0806… trt   untrt       126 SRX384354  SRS50… SAMN0242… #>  #> $gene #> # A tibble: 6 × 10 #>   gene_id   gene_name entrezid gene_biotype gene_seq_start gene_seq_end seq_name #>   <chr>     <chr>     <lgl>    <chr>                 <int>        <int> <chr>    #> 1 ENSG0000… TSPAN6    NA       protein_cod…       99883667     99894988 X        #> 2 ENSG0000… TNMD      NA       protein_cod…       99839799     99854882 X        #> 3 ENSG0000… DPM1      NA       protein_cod…       49551404     49575092 20       #> 4 ENSG0000… SCYL3     NA       protein_cod…      169818772    169863408 1        #> 5 ENSG0000… C1orf112  NA       protein_cod…      169631245    169823221 1        #> 6 ENSG0000… FGR       NA       protein_cod…       27938575     27961788 1        #> # ℹ 3 more variables: seq_strand <int>, seq_coord_system <lgl>, symbol <chr> #>  #> $expr #> # A tibble: 6 × 9 #>   gene_id      SRR1039508 SRR1039509 SRR1039512 SRR1039513 SRR1039516 SRR1039517 #>   <chr>             <int>      <int>      <int>      <int>      <int>      <int> #> 1 ENSG0000000…        679        448        873        408       1138       1047 #> 2 ENSG0000000…          0          0          0          0          0          0 #> 3 ENSG0000000…        467        515        621        365        587        799 #> 4 ENSG0000000…        260        211        263        164        245        331 #> 5 ENSG0000000…         60         55         40         35         78         63 #> 6 ENSG0000000…          0          0          2          0          1          0 #> # ℹ 2 more variables: SRR1039520 <int>, SRR1039521 <int> airway$expr <- airway$expr |>      pivot_longer(         names_to = "Run", values_to = "expr", cols = 2:last_col()     ) head(airway$expr) #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>   gene_id         Run         expr #>   <chr>           <chr>      <int> #> 1 ENSG00000000003 SRR1039508   679 #> 2 ENSG00000000003 SRR1039509   448 #> 3 ENSG00000000003 SRR1039512   873 #> 4 ENSG00000000003 SRR1039513   408 #> 5 ENSG00000000003 SRR1039516  1138 #> 6 ENSG00000000003 SRR1039517  1047 merged_data <- airway$expr |>      left_join(airway$gene, by = "gene_id") |>      left_join(airway$sample, by = "Run") head(merged_data) #> # A tibble: 6 × 20 #>   gene_id         Run        expr gene_name entrezid gene_biotype gene_seq_start #>   <chr>           <chr>     <int> <chr>     <lgl>    <chr>                 <int> #> 1 ENSG00000000003 SRR10395…   679 TSPAN6    NA       protein_cod…       99883667 #> 2 ENSG00000000003 SRR10395…   448 TSPAN6    NA       protein_cod…       99883667 #> 3 ENSG00000000003 SRR10395…   873 TSPAN6    NA       protein_cod…       99883667 #> 4 ENSG00000000003 SRR10395…   408 TSPAN6    NA       protein_cod…       99883667 #> 5 ENSG00000000003 SRR10395…  1138 TSPAN6    NA       protein_cod…       99883667 #> 6 ENSG00000000003 SRR10395…  1047 TSPAN6    NA       protein_cod…       99883667 #> # ℹ 13 more variables: gene_seq_end <int>, seq_name <chr>, seq_strand <int>, #> #   seq_coord_system <lgl>, symbol <chr>, SampleName <chr>, cell <chr>, #> #   dex <chr>, albut <chr>, avgLength <int>, Experiment <chr>, Sample <chr>, #> #   BioSample <chr> airway_summary <- merged_data |>      select(gene_name, dex, expr) |>      group_by(gene_name, dex) |>      summarise(         mean = mean(expr, na.rm = TRUE),         sd = sd(expr, na.rm = TRUE),         n = n()     ) head(airway_summary) #> # A tibble: 6 × 5 #> # Groups:   gene_name [3] #>   gene_name dex      mean     sd     n #>   <chr>     <chr>   <dbl>  <dbl> <int> #> 1 5S_rRNA   trt   0.00962 0.0981   104 #> 2 5S_rRNA   untrt 0.0288  0.218    104 #> 3 7SK       trt   0.292   0.798     48 #> 4 7SK       untrt 0.104   0.371     48 #> 5 A1BG      trt   6       2.94       4 #> 6 A1BG      untrt 9       2.16       4
